G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 28, a Probate and Family Court may modify its prior judgment as to the care, custody, and maintenance of minor children “as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Similarly, G.L. c. 209C, § 20 authorizes the Court to modify custody and parenting time orders regarding children born to unmarried parents upon a showing of a material and substantial change in circumstances and where modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31; G.L. c.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to, inter alia, G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6, and the Court’s general equity powers in domestic relations matters.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under G.L. c. 208, § 31, in allocating custody and parenting time, the Court must consider the best interests of the child, including, among other factors, the child’s physical, emotional, and developmental needs, the child’s relationship with each parent, and the capacity of each parent to meet those needs.

G.L. c. 215.proposition: COMPLAINT FOR MODIFICATION (G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 208, § 31; G.L. c. 215)

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to, inter alia, G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31; G.L. c. 209C, § 20; G.L. c. 215, §§ 3, 6, and the Court’s general equity powers in domestic relations matters.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount and governing standard in child custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the “best interests of the child” standard as the governing standard for custody determinations in Massachusetts, tracing its historical roots and reaffirming that custody under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a) is to be awarded as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child. It also cites prior Massachusetts cases stating that the best interests of the children remain the paramount concern in custody decisions. Thus the case squarely supports the proposition that best interests is the paramount and controlling standard for custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840 (200.relevant_excerpt: “Section 10 (a) gives a probate judge the power to award custody of nonmarital children ‘to the mother or the father or to them jointly ... as may be appropriate in the best interests of the child.’ … The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”}

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount and governing standard in child custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses how domestic violence must be expressly considered in custody decisions and references the statutory requirement to consider such violence in relation to the child’s welfare, but the provided excerpt does not state or reaffirm the broad doctrinal rule that the best interests of the child is the paramount standard in all Massachusetts custody and parenting time determinations. That general principle is assumed in the background and referenced indirectly through statutes, rather than being articulated or analyzed as the governing standard. Therefore, this case is not strong authority for that specific proposition, even though it is consistent with it.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595 (1.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that “[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody . . . the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.” … We agree with the Appeals Court that such written findings should also be made attending specifically to the effects of domestic violence on the child and the appropriateness of the joint custody award in light of those effects.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257, 265–266 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: The “best interests of the child” is the paramount and governing standard in child custody and parenting time determinations in Massachusetts.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames both custody modification and removal determinations in terms of the child’s best interests as the governing standard. When discussing G. L. c. 208, § 28, the court states that modification is permissible only if necessary in the best interests of the children, and later, in the removal analysis, it reiterates that “the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern.” This aligns directly with the proposition that best interests are the paramount and governing standard in Massachusetts custody and parenting time cases.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt:
“Our decision today, that a request for modification of custody is distinct from a request to relocate and must be based on a material and substantial change in circumstances other than the move, is consistent with these decisions and with G. L. c. 208, § 28 (‘the court may make a judgment modifying its earlier judgment as to the care and custody of the minor children of the parties provided that the court finds that a material and substantial change in circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the children’).”

“Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.proposition: To modify an existing custody or parenting time order, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.support_reasoning: The case deals with modification of alimony and child support under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28 and 37, not with modification of custody or parenting time. It states that a party seeking to modify support must show a material change in circumstances, and then the judge considers the needs of the children and the circumstances of the parties, but it does not articulate or apply a two-part standard for modifying custody/parenting time or frame the analysis explicitly in “best interests of the child” terms for a custody order. Thus it cannot be cited as authority for the specific custody/parenting‑time proposition stated.
Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368\u.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28… The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”

M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 231\u201323.proposition: To modify an existing custody or parenting time order, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 231\u201323.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns standards for setting child support where parents share legal and physical custody and have incomes beyond the Child Support Guidelines range. It does not deal with modification of an existing custody or parenting time order, nor does it articulate a standard requiring a material and substantial change in circumstances plus best interests of the child for modifying such orders. The only reference to change of circumstances is in the context of potential future modification of child support, not custody or parenting time.
M.C. v. T.K., 463 Mass. 226, 231\u201323.relevant_excerpt: "On remand, the judge is not required to revisit the issue of the father’s income at the time of trial, but should consider whether the circumstances have materially changed since the date of the judgment before us, and should base any award of child support on the parties’ current incomes."

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 900 (1981)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: To modify an existing custody or parenting time order, the moving party must demonstrate (1) a material and substantial change in circumstances since the prior judgment, and (2) that modification is in the best interests of the child.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the proper criteria for an initial custody award in a divorce judgment, focusing on the welfare and best interests of the child. It does not address modification of an existing custody or parenting-time order, nor does it set out any requirement of showing a material and substantial change in circumstances. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the two-prong modification standard stated in the proposition.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’ (emphasis supplied). ... This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. ... The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child."

Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.raw_text: Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146, 150–152 (2015)
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that changes in a child’s age, developmental needs, schooling, and the parents’ living circumstances may constitute a material change justifying a new parenting schedule.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal and child-support modification case, not a parenting-time or parenting-schedule modification case. The court discusses the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal framework and best interests factors (including children’s developmental needs), but it does not analyze what constitutes a ‘material change’ to justify revising a parenting schedule, nor does it identify changes in age, developmental needs, schooling, or parents’ living circumstances as such a material change. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
Murray v. Super, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146,.relevant_excerpt: “The relevant factors are: (1) whether the quality of the children’s lives will be improved, including any improvement that ‘may flow from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life’; (2) any possible ‘adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child[ren]’s association with the noncustodial parent’; (3) ‘the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the [children’s] emotional, physical, or developmental needs’; (4) the interests of both parents; and (5) the possibility of an alternative visitation schedule for the noncustodial parent.’”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.proposition: The Court must also consider whether an order will promote stability, predictability, and the child’s overall well‑being, including educational and emotional needs.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion reiterates the general rule that the controlling consideration in custody cases is the child’s welfare, including consideration of the probable future, but it does not specifically articulate that the court must consider stability, predictability, or the child’s educational and emotional needs as distinct required factors. Those concepts are implicit in the facts (e.g., noting who cared for the child’s physical and emotional needs) rather than set out as a legal standard. Thus the case supports the broad ‘best interests/welfare’ principle, not the more detailed proposition stated.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406, 409 (1.relevant_excerpt: “In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and the wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the child in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future, and it is a subject peculiarly within the discretion of the judge.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 403–404 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: Where both parents are loving and fit, maintaining and fostering a healthy, ongoing relationship with both parents is strongly favored, as long as it serves the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly endorses the general principle that children should have frequent and continuing contact with both parents and that they are usually better off if parents can share in responsibility and physical custody, subject to the best-interests standard. Although the court upholds sole custody and reduced visitation on these particular facts, it does so as an application of the best-interests test and not as a rejection of the underlying preference for ongoing relationships with both loving, fit parents.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that “the law sees a value in ‘frequent and continuing contact’ of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.” … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: Courts have recognized that parenting‑time arrangements that once served a child’s best interests may become outdated as the child grows and circumstances change, warranting modification.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion is about an initial custody and removal determination at the time of divorce, not about modifying an existing parenting-time or custody order because prior arrangements had become outdated as the children grew or circumstances changed. The court discusses how to assess the children’s best interests and visitation in the context of relocation, but it does not address post‑judgment modification of parenting‑time arrangements over time. Therefore it does not provide authority for the proposition concerning later modification of outdated parenting schedules.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”
